title: Remove empty folder and unused code for testnet
body:
Delete old, obsolete and unused code ahead of testnet launch.
We don't want to confuse folks with code that won't run or have
unnecessary folders with nothing in them.

Code can be recovered from the git history if any of these projects need
to be resurrected. For rference, the following folders were deleted:

* grpc_wallet
* console_text_messenger
* cli_wallet
* tari_miner
* tari_pool_miner
* base_layer/mining
* digital_assets_layer
* doc (about as outdated as anything in here :/)

And some bash scripts were updated to reflect this.

title: windows compatibility changes
body:
## Description
Windows build and test compatibility

## Motivation and Context
Test files cleanup
- In Windows, files cannot be deleted if the filehandles are not closed beforehand. Added scope brackets to tests where required.

Line endings
- Git manages line endings on Windows vs. Linix, so `cargo-fmt --all` needs to use the `newline_style = "Native"` setting to be compatible between the two systems.
- Needed to pass platform-agnostic line ending pattern to the `std::string::String split()` method to read test data

## How Has This Been Tested?
- Tests for all changed components passed on Windows 10. Issues with `tari_wallet` still need to be sorted out. probably due to C dependencies.
- Tests passed in Linux Ubuntu.

title: Builder dry
body:
## DRY up node builder
    
* The node builder has been cleaned up significantly.
* The `BlockchainBackend` has been abstracted away behind a  `NodeContainer` enum that exposes a set of methods that   are backend-agnostic.
* This lets us remove all the duplicated code in the builder logic.
* All the functions in the builder have been refactored to have a *single responsibility*.
    
## Other changes
* The miner builder code has been collected up and grouped together.
* A hash rate calculator hash been added to `blake_miner`.
    
    Every minute, if a block hasn't been found, it'll log the hashrate to
    the logs (in MH/s).


* Many log messages have been added to the code, the mining code in
    particular.
    
## Please check
_Please check_: The miner did not start because the `new_block_found`
 flag was initially set to false, which put the mining thread in a
 perpetual loop; and it never got to ask for a template. The thing is, I
 don't know how mining ever worked before with this code, so I'd love to
 know if there's anything I've broken.

title: Don't redial peer for a while if they cannot be contacted
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Currently, if we cannot send to a peer the user of `MessagingProtocol`
has no way to know if the peer is not contactable.

This PR notifies the requester if they attempting to dial a peer which was not
contactable within a cooldown period (1 minute) so that they have some
way to handle that (give up, retry later etc).

The messaging protocol provides the following reasons as to why a message
failed to send:
```rust
pub enum SendFailReason {
    /// Dial was not attempted because the peer is offline
    PeerOffline,
    /// Dial was attempted, but failed
    PeerDialFailed,
    /// Outbound message envelope failed to serialize
    EnvelopeFailedToSerialize,
    /// Failed to open a messaging substream to peer
    SubstreamOpenFailed,
    /// Failed to send on substream channel
    SubstreamSendFailed,
}
```


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1371 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->

title: Fix block syncing for competing chains
body:
## Description
- Modified the block syncing logic, it starts with the network tip and downloads the blocks in reverse until the local chain is reached, resulting in a chain reorganisation. 
- Modified the add_block logic so that each new block is first added as an orphan, this allows a full fork chain to be reconstructed, making use of previously received orphan blocks, before it is added to the main chain. Previously when a newly received block was added to the tip, the orphan blocks that build on the newly received block was never used to extend the chain.
- Added a FetchBlockWithHashes request and Blocks response to the base node and the inbound handler. This request function allows chain and orphan blocks to be requested from remote nodes.
- A static lifetime constraint was added on the blockchain backend generic of the state machine to allow async calls to the db.
- Fixed issue with the Rincewind genesis block, the difficulties cannot be zero as the geometric mean calculation will fail.
- Added a random nonce to chained test blocks and forced the difficulty to 1, this will help with some of the flaky chain tests.

## Motivation and Context
This change will enable improved syncing when the network has competing chains.

## How Has This Been Tested?
- Added the request_and_response_fetch_blocks_with_hashes test that demonstrates the new fetch block base node service request and response system.
- Added the test_forked_block_sync test, this test demonstrates syncing when there are two competing chains.
- Added the store_and_retrieve_chain_and_orphan_blocks_with_hashes test.

title: Integrate the Comms Event Bus feedback into the Wallet Send Transaction
body:
## Description
The Comms stack now has an event bus that informs you when a message has been successfully sent where before you only knew it had been queued for sending after a discovery process has been successful.

This PR updates the Transaction Service to start monitoring the Messaging Events to wait for the confirmation that the message has sent or failed to send. If the message failed to send the client application will be informed via a Callback that the transaction Failed to send.

## Motivation and Context
Closes https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/1260

Tests updated and provided

title: Add crate caching and parallel operation to circleCI
body:
* Cache the target and crate registries so that subsequent pushes
      don't have to re-download and build the dependencies
 * Run debug and release tests in parallel pipelines to try and
      speed up overall builds

All builds prior to this were taking ±35min.

Cold builds (i.e. with dependency changes) should run about 5-7min quicker due to release and debug being in parallel.

Subsequent pushes may be up to 50% faster (depending on how far caching got). This PR took 16min to build from a hot start.

title: MempoolService: handle add block and reorg events
body:
## Description
- Changed the mempool service so that it listens to block events from the base node, a block event handler was added to allow the mempool to react to add block events and chain re-org events.
- Changed the inbound block handler of the base node to allow the network propagation of received blocks that produced a re-org of the local chain.
- Modified the blockchain database rewind_to_height and reorganize_chain functions so they return the blocks that were removed, these removed blocks are required to process a re-org in the mempool.
- The BlockAddResult ChainReorg event was changed to allow the mempool service event handler to obtain the set of added and removed blocks. 
- Replaced the PoisonedAccess error type with a BackendError in the OrphanPoolError, PendingPoolError, ReorgPoolError and UnconfirmedPoolError.
- Changed some of the test block builder functions to allow the creation of coinbases with configurable maturity.

## Motivation and Context
These changes are required to allow the mempool state to be updated when new blocks were added to the blockchain or a chain re-organisation was performed.

## How Has This Been Tested?
Added the mempool test block_event_and_reorg_event_handling for checking that the mempool service is correctly reacting to add block events and chain re-org events.

title: Prevent Multiple Threads from Writing in LMDB
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Added a (hopefully) better lock for the LMDBDatabase struct. In the current implementation there is the possibility of two threads entering `write()` and interleaving, leaving the state of the in memory members (e..g `uxto_mmr`, `utxo_checkpoints`) of `LMDBDatabase` in an inconsistent state.

For example, one thread could be in `reset_mmrs()` and another in `commit_mmrs()`, resulting in some MMRs having old data and some having new data.

I think there could be more improvement to how we are utilising the LMDB transactions, but since there is also in memory state on the struct I think a lock over the whole struct is necessary
 
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
If not done, the data in memory and in the database could become corrupt and unsalvageable. 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Difficult to test, but the current tests still pass

title: Add checksum algorithm
body:
The luhn mod 1024 checksum is added to allow us to detect transposition
errors in emoji ids. Luhn was selected over e.g. Damm becuase the Damm
algorithm was developed for 10-digit "alphabets", whereas we have a 1024
digit alphabet.

The weaknesses of the Luhn algorithm (missing some errors) are mitigated
as the alphabet size increases, so the false positive rate for emoji ids
should be neglibly small.

title: Recovery mode if an error occurs during BlockSync
body:
## Description
- Modified the block sync logic to enable redownloading missing blocks or received blocks that haven't passed block validation. Bad blocks will be ignored and requested again from the network.
- Block sync was also changed so that only one block is downloaded at a time, this simplified determining what blocks were received and which blocks should be requested again.
- The block_sync_chunk_size was removed from BlockSyncConfig and max_block_request_retry_attempts was added to specify how many times the current node should attempt to request the block at a specific height again from different peer nodes.
- The MaxRequestAttemptsReached state event was added to allow a node that has exceeded the maximum request attempts to transition to the InitialSync state and attempt to reestablish communication with the network.

## Motivation and Context
This change will make the block sync process more reliable as blocks can be requested again without switching to a different state machine state. 

## How Has This Been Tested?
A test_block_sync_recovery test was added that demonstrates that when a remote node responds with an empty response to a download request, the request will be repeated a limited number of times to other random nodes until the correct blocks could be retrieved.

title: Implement Base Node Syncing for Wallet Output Manager Service
body:
## Description

This PR implements the functionality for the Output Manager to query the base node to confirm the status of stored Unspent Outputs as UTXO’s that exist on the blockchain. If the UTXOs do not exist then the Unspent Outputs and moved to the Invalid Outputs collection.

This sync function is called when the Base Node Public Key is first set and an FFI API call is provided for the frontend to call the function whenever it feels it is required.

An event bus is also added to the Output Manager Service.

## Motivation and Context
This functionality is meant to help a wallet make sure its state is consistent with that is on the blockchain. If a wallet is copied and the other copy spends some of the outputs when the first wallet starts up it will have an incorrect balance so this will allow the first wallet to sync its state by querying the base node.

title: Base node listening state
body:
## Description
- Implemented the listening logic for the BaseNodeStateMachine. It listens for chain metadata events received from the liveness and chain metadata service. If it detects that the current node is lagging behind the network it will switch to the block sync state. When no metadata was received for a prolonged period of time it will transition to the initial sync state, where it will request chain metadata from remote nodes. 
- Modified the BaseNodeStateMachine to have access to the executor and metadata event stream.
- Also added an extra state transition in the BaseNodeStateMachine,allowing the node to transition from the listening state to the InitialSync state when network silence was detected.
- Moved the determine_sync_mode function to a helpers.rs file, to allow the listening state and initial sync to reuse the same function. 
- Added the ChainMetadataService handle to the construction of the base node in the base node builder.

## Motivation and Context
These changes will allow the BaseNodeStateMachine to react on the received chain metadata from remote nodes by performing a block sync when it detects that the current node is lagging. It will also detect prolonged periods of not receiving any chain metadata, allowing it to request chain metadata from its peers.

## How Has This Been Tested?
- Added the test_listening_lagging test that demonstrates the detection of a lagging state and the transition to the block sync state.
- Added the test_listening_network_silence test that demonstrates the internal timeout system for detecting prolonged network silence.

title: Comms builder for fully-async comms node
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Comms builder is the public interface for building a comms node. This PR
is an iteration on the previous builder which brings together all the new
async services.

It now handles hooking up the inbound and outbound "pipelines"
to the /tari/messaging protocol. (This used to be an external
responsibility). This interface is fully compatible with the existing pipeline (dht, tari_p2p etc)

It also allows custom protocols to be added.

An example initialization:

```rust
  let comms_node = CommsBuilder::new()
        .with_listener_address("/ip4/0.0.0.0/tcp/0".parse().unwrap())
        .with_transport(TcpTransport::default())
        .with_peer_storage(HashmapDatabase::new())
        .with_messaging_pipeline(
            pipeline::Builder::new()
                // Outbound messages will be forwarded "as is" to outbound messaging
                .with_outbound_pipeline(outbound_rx, std::convert::identity)
               // Up to 10 inbound messages concurrently processed by the given pipeline 
                .max_concurrent_inbound_tasks(10)
                // Inbound messages will be forwarded "as is" to inbound_tx
                .with_inbound_pipeline(SinkService::new(inbound_tx))
                .finish(),
        )
        .with_node_identity(node_identity)
        .with_protocols(
           Protocols::new()
             // Add protocol ids and notifiers (mpsc::Sender). Notifications are sent when a peer wants to speak a particular protocol
               .add(&[MY_CUSTOM_PROTOCOL_v1, MY_CUSTOM_PROTOCOL_v2], my_custom_notif)
               .add(&[DHT_PROTOCOL], dht_notif)
               .add(&[MEMPOOL_PROTOCOL], mempool_notif)
        )
        .spawn()
        .await
        .unwrap();
```


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1235 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->

title: Chain synchronisation, MerkleChangeTracker disconnect and Backend checkpoint creation
body:
## Description
- The blockchain db backends (memory_db and lmdb_db) were made responsible for checkpoint creation and rewinding. The MerkleChange tracker was replaced with a simpler MmrCache that is only responsible for calculating Merkle and Merklish roots.
- The persistent storage of the base mmr was removed from the lmdb_db, the base mmr is recreated using the MmrCache.
- Deprecated unused blockchain db and backend functions: fetch_mmr_base_leaf_nodes, fetch_mmr_base_leaf_node_count, assign_mmr, fetch_horizon_block_height and validate_horizon_state.
- Fixed issue with the blockchain db rewind_to_height function, where it was double deleting block hashes.
- Removed the horizon syncing state from the base node state machine as the node will run as an archival node. Horizon syncing will be reintroduced at a later stage.
- Removed the horizon syncing logic and horizon header validator as these are unused at the the moment
- Modified the initial sync to immediately start with the block syncing when the network has a higher tip than the current node.
- Replaced the MerkleChangeTracker with the MmrCache and backend checkpoint management system. - The unused MerkleChangeTracker was removed.
- Replaced the MerkleChangeTrackerConfig with MmrCacheConfig for changing the settings of the MmrCache, it no longer requires knowledge of the horizon block height.
- The MemBackendVec a shareable memory only vector was introduced in tari_mmr that can be used for checkpoint testing.
- The MerkleCheckpoint was moved to its own file. as the MerkleChangeTracker was deprecated.
- Removed the fetch mmr state requests, responses and handlers from the Base node service. Also removed the proto conversions for these message types.

## Motivation and Context
The following changes were performed to change the base node into a full archival node and split the multiple responsibilities of the MerkleChangeTracker, Merkle and Merklish root calculations are now performed by the MmrCache and the checkpoint creation, updates and rewinds are performed by the blockchain backends.

## How Has This Been Tested?
- The test_block_sync and test_lagging_block_sync test were altered to not perform horizon syncing.
- The blockchain storage fetch_checkpoint test was extended to ensure that memory_db and lmdb_db backends had similar behaviour.
- Tests were added for the MmrCache and MemBackendVec.
- A number of unused tests were deprecated: assign_mmr, request_and_response_fetch_mmr_state, test_horizon_state_sync, fetch_mmr_base_leaf_nodes_and_restore.

title: Implement wallet base node monitoring for broadcast transactions
body:
## Description

This PR implements base node monitoring for the Wallet to periodically ask a base_node if a pending CompletedTransaction has been mined yet.

When a Completed transaction is detected as broadcast to the mempool the Wallet will start querying the base_node for the outputs that have been mined.

When the wallet starts up it will go through stored completed transactions and check which have the broadcast state and start monitoring them for being mined

Closes https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/640

title: Added fire-and-forget Messaging protocol handler
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- Added protocol `/tari/messaging/0.1.0`
- This protocol handler handles inbound and outbound messaging.
- The node must already be connected to the peer before sending/receiving messages.
- Peers sending `/tari/messaging/0.1.0` messages between each other open
  two substreams (lazily, as needed), one for inbound and one for
  outbound.
- Outbound messages are sent as a request to MessagingProtocol. If a
  substream is not open for this peer, one is opened and 'cached' for
  future message sends.
- This protocol handler will be hooked up to the existing OMS and IMS.
  Essentially it is the glue between the existing fire-and-forget functionality
  and the async multiplexed connections.


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->

title: Miner wallet integration
body:
## Description
Miner wallet integration.
Cleanup the miner code and moved mining to a blocking thread.

## Motivation and Context
The miner needs to be able to submit a utxo to the wallet. The miner cannot contain a wallet as this will cause a cycle dependancy. The base node will act as a mediator between the two. The miner gives a channel out to the base node which will sit and listen for an unblindedUTXO which it will give to wallet

The miner code has also been moved to a blocking thread as spawning a task is not the most efficient use of blocking task. The mining task will wait for the blocking thread to return and does not use a thread anymore with channels to communicate internally.

title: Implement completed transaction broadcast for wallet
body:
## Description
When a Sender receives the the Transaction Reply from a Receiver the transaction is completed and is ready to be broadcast to the base node mempool.

This PR implements the process for the wallet to attempt to broadcast a completed TX to its registered Base Node and then request from that base node whether the transaction has been received or not. The broadcast will be repeated until the base node mempool reports the transaction is present in the mempool.

This PR also moves the Callback handler into the Wallet_FFI library which is really where it belongs.

## Motivation and Context
Closes: https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/881
Towards: https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/640

title: Resolve issue #1132
body:
As per the discussion in #1132, the failing test, `check_pruning_of_pruned_mmr`
is a case of the expected behaviour of the class and how it was designed
to work being at odds.

Part of this confusion stems from ChangeTracker not having a Single
Responsiblity.

Therefore, we've decided to proceed as follows:

* Blockchain data synchronisation does not need to have anything to do
with a ChangeTracker if the CheckPoint data (the additions / deletions
per block) are promoted to first-class citizens in the backing database.
* Then the moving window history that requires the `base` mmr field to
be mutable can be removed. the `base` MMR can then be immutable as
originally intended.
* The ChangeTracker's resposibility is thus i) keeping track of the
chain tip MMR root. ii) Holding state necessary for perorming re-orgs.

Whoops, It still has multiple responsibilities!

Ok, a single PrunableMMR stored in memory can be used to keep track of
the chain tip MMR root. The databse backend implementation can choose to
periodically "re-base" the in-memory instance from time to time so that
the data structure does not grow indefinitely.

And rewind logic is a matter of truncating the checkpoint storage and
rebasing the tip's MMR instance.

Goodbye ChangeTracker, it was nice knowing you. Goodbye #1132

closes #1132

title: Simultaneous connection tie breaking
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
If peers dial each other at the same time there must be a way for both
peers to deterministically choose which connection to keep and which to
disconnect.

This PR adds code to handle this situation by using the NodeID and
ConnectionDirection to enable both sides to agree on a connection to
close.

Extra: Since async tests are moving towards to running in an async context (through `#[tokio_macros::test]` - tests should probably change to use this) it no longer makes sense to use `tari_test_utils::runtime` and `Runtime::block_on` everywhere.  I changed `tari_test_utils::collect_stream!` to rather work in an async context. 

## Motivation and Context

connections simultaneously. Each inbound connection spawns it's own

title: Added bounded executor
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Spawning an unbounded number of tasks in response to e.g. a network message
is dangerous because an attacker could exploit this to cause a node to become
unresponsive/use excessive system resources.

This PR adds a `BoundedExecutor` which wraps the tokio executor and a
semaphore to asynchronously block calls to spawn should all the semaphore
permits be used. This should cause backpressure on the requesting peer.
For e.g. new requests won't be handled until a permit has been
released.

BONUS: removed some unused dependencies

title: Check and fix re-org logic
body:
## Description
- The handle_reorg function was updated to allow the construction of forked chains from newly received orphan blocks. The orphan chain tip with the highest accumulated difficulty that is linked to the new orphan block is found. A chain is then constructed from the tip to the new orphan block all the way to the main chain. When the total accumulated difficulty is higher than the tip of the main chain then a chain reorganisation is performed. 
- Added the total_accumulated_with_achieved_difficulty member function to BlockHeader, this allows the total accumulated difficulty for the blockchain at that height including the achieved difficulty to be determined.
- Changed the default difficulty to 1 as the geometric mean calculation fails when the difficulty is 0. Some tests had to be updated with new nonces to accommodate the change.
- Additional block builder helper functions were added to enable testing of blocks with specific achieved difficulties.

## Motivation and Context
The new reorg logic handles more special cases such as orphan blocks that are received out of order.

## How Has This Been Tested?
The handle_reorg test was updated to include a more comprehensive test and a handle_tip_reorg test was added to test the simpler case where the newly received block is the tip.

title: Origin in DHT message is now optional, hash of message for dedup
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- Origin data (public key and signature) are optional to preserve
  privacy for appropriate messages (e.g. transactions, blocks)
- If the origin is omitted, the message is from the peer
  sending the message over a secure channel
- The deduping of messages uses a hash of the message contents, not the
   origin signature. This is to prevent a duplicate message signed by a
   different party from being let through.
- SAF storage keeps a copy of cleartext messages that have an origin
  specified
- Shared SAF storage access uses the blocking threadpool


## Motivation and Context
